awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Retrofit Dehumidifiers to Enable Greater than 50% Air Conditioner Energy Savings Via Elimination of Latent Loads
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on the development of retrofit dehumidification systems for air conditioners (AC) to reduce latent loads and save more than 50% of the energy consumed by AC systems. Air conditioners consume more than $230 billion in energy annually worldwide, accounting for more than 4% of total global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. The goal of this SBIR Phase I project is to develop a drop-in solution for existing AC infrastructure to enable substantial reductions in energy use and operating costs for AC systems. These drop-in dehumidification systems have the potential to save the industry > $100 billion in energy costs and up to 1 gigaton of CO2 emissions annually. The innovation developed in this project will help mitigate the effects of global climate change, while simultaneously ensuring access to affordable cooling systems globally by helping substantially reduce operating costs for AC systems.

The intellectual merit of this project is in its utilization of a droplet filtration method, initially pioneered for space applications. This filtration method enables retrofit dehumidifiers that are powered by a liquid desiccant spray reactor that enables high-rate, high-efficiency dehumidification. The dehumidification approach in this project is differentiated from other state-of-the-art methods on the market today due to the method of liquid desiccant deployment, which enables high surface area contact between liquids and gasses. The filtration method enables high-efficiency dehumidification by capturing nearly 100% of fine droplets (<30 micrometers) at very low pressure drop (<100 Pascals) using three distinct filter length-scales. The meter-scale filters are additively manufactured with millimeter-scale helical pores that enable low-pressure-drop inertial capture of fine droplets, which are absorbed in the micrometer-scale porous medium of the filters via capillary forces. These filters enable dehumidifiers that operate 6-8x more efficiently than other methods on the market today and have very high process rates, resulting in a 20-fold reduction in system volume compared to other technologies. This Phase I project will mature the dehumidifiers from a lab-scale proof of concept to a system prototype for a window-scale AC unit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through the NSF Phase I award, Helix Earth Technologies (HET) developed a groundbreaking retrofit dehumidification system, the Helix MICRA™ dehumidifier, which promises to revolutionize energy efficiency in air conditioning (AC) systems. The primary goal of the project was to address the energy-intensive challenge posed by parasitic latent loads in AC systems, particularly in humid climates. These latent loads significantly increase energy use, and with AC systems contributing 4% of global CO2 emissions, there is an urgent need for more sustainable solutions. Our retrofit system is designed to save more than 50% of the energy consumed by existing AC systems, offering a scalable, cost-effective solution to a major environmental problem.

Intellectual Merit

The Helix MICRA™ dehumidifier represents a significant advancement in the science of liquid-gas chemistry and energy-efficient cooling technologies. The key innovation behind this system is the Helix MICRA™ filter, which captures micrometer-scale droplets (< 30 micron) of liquid desiccant at very high efficiency (~100%) and at a very low pressure drop (< 100 Pa). This enables a high-rate dehumidification process that is 10-20 times faster than conventional technologies. This rapid rate results in systems that are compact and cost-effective, which makes it ideal for retrofitting into existing AC units, drastically reducing energy consumption. In Phase I, we successfully advanced the system from a lab-scale (TRL 4) to a commercial-scale prototype (TRL 6), demonstrating energy savings and performance across a range of environmental conditions.

Key technical accomplishments include:

- Scaling the Helix MICRA™ filter for commercial use, including the development of 3D printing and injection molding methods for manufacturing.

- Optimizing the droplet capture process and spray reactor to achieve dehumidification rates exceeding 2,300 kg/hr/m³.

- Developing an energy-efficient liquid desiccant regeneration process, with a coefficient of performance (COP) greater than 5, further reducing the system's energy demand.

Broader Impacts

The Helix MICRA™ dehumidification system has broad societal and environmental impacts, particularly in reducing the carbon footprint of commercial and industrial cooling systems. By targeting energy savings in humid climates, where 80% of the U.S. population resides, this technology has the potential to make a significant dent in global CO2 emissions. The scalability of the system means it can be applied in residential, commercial, and industrial settings. The system is readily scalable, which means it offers an accessible solution to a wide range of users, roughly 80% of the cooling market. 

Beyond environmental benefits, the Helix MICRA™ dehumidifiers will create economic opportunities by providing businesses with a cost-effective way to reduce their energy bills. For example, pilot customers are already seeing the financial and environmental advantages of installing the Helix MICRA™ dehumidifiers, and are ready to adopt the technology. To date, we have a waitlist of over 300 interested customers and have formed partnerships with major HVAC manufacturers like the Hunton Group. We are set up to expand the impact of this technology on a national and global scale.

Our Phase I effort also placed a strong emphasis on workforce development and diversity in engineering. Through partnerships with Rice University and targeted outreach, we provided hands-on research opportunities to students from underrepresented groups in STEM, contributing to a more diverse pipeline of future engineers. 

Looking Ahead 

The successful completion of Phase I has set the stage for an ambitious Phase II effort, where we plan to pilot the Helix MICRA™ system in a variety of commercial environments and further refine the technology to TRL 8 high-fidelity commercial system. Our next steps involve scaling the manufacturing process, conducting pilot tests with key commercial partners, and continuing to expand our team and collaborations to bring this energy-saving technology to the market. The Helix MICRA™ dehumidifier has the potential to transform how we approach energy efficiency in cooling systems, and with continued development and support, it will play a critical role in the global effort to reduce energy consumption and combat climate change.


Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Rawand M Rasheed
